author: Nigel Thompson
title: Halloween breaks and events to put the frighteners on a fun day out
text:
Believe it or not, there was a time in the dim and distant past when kids of all ages got excited about Bonfire Night – and Halloween was relatively unimportant.
Nowadays, of course, All Hallows’ Evening – to give it its full name – is big business worldwide and, of course, big fun.
The celebrations of the thwarting of the Gunpowder Plot of November 5, 1605 seems almost obscure in comparison. Guy who?
Here’s the pick of this year’s Halloween events...
Edinburgh The scares are below the stairs in Auld Reekie with the underground Dark Truth tour at The Real Mary King’s Close.
Step beneath the Royal Mile to unearth the real stories and villainous characters of the Scottish capital’s murky past, including Kincaid the Witch Pricker and body snatcher William Burke.
The hour-long evening experience is for over-16s and costs £14.95 with advance booking recommended and is on four times a night from October 28-31. realmarykingsclose.com
Staffordshire Haunted house: The Halloween Spooktacular at Shugborough
The Halloween Spooktacular at Shugborough Estate, near Stafford, is on October 31.
It will see the mansion house and servants’ quarters transformed into a creepy haunted house with a ghost train, fun fair and Zombee garden in the grounds.
Admission: adult £11 in advance, £13 on the night/child £8.50 or £10.50/family £34 or £40. Under 5s free, parking free. www.shugborough.org.uk
Family frights: Alton Towers
Down the road there’s the annual Scarefest on to November 1 at Alton Towers. This year’s has two new horror mazes – the Haunting of Molly Crowe, where visitors are blindfolded, and Sub-Species: The End Games, where post-apocalyptic sewer dwellers await.
The newest showpiece is Operation Lockdown, an intense two hour escape room experience for over 18s. Brave youngsters can learn how to spook with Phil’s Ghoul School, listen to Skelvin’s Spooky Storytime and join in Patch’s Trick or Treat Party.
Admission from £37.80 adult/£33.30 child, mazes are £8 each, two for £15, or all three for £20. Operation Lockdown from £99 per person. altontowers.com
London Horror story: London Dungeon's Master of Tricks
The London Dungeon’s Halloween season is on now to November 1 and the highlight is a new Seance show featuring celebrated Victorian spirit medium Florence Cook.
Set in 1873, the spooky seance experience will see visitors to the County Hall attraction joining Florence in her chamber as she communicates with the spirit world... leading to a climactic visitation.
Recommended for age 12 and over. Admission from £25.95 adult/£20.95 child. thedungeons.com/London
Warwickshire Warwick Castle has its Haunted Castle sessions on from today to November 1.
While it’s family-friendly fun as normal during the day, after dark the fear factor kicks in with six new Halloween events including horseback fire jousting and the live-actor attraction Outbreak 1349 based on the Black Death. And just for good measure a headless horseman will be roaming the grounds.
After dark admission starts at £12. warwick-castle.com
Cornwall Creepy: Witchcraft at the Eden Project
Positive potions and freaky fun are in the mix for the Eden Project’s Halloweden week, which starts today.
Families will embark on a mystical journey through the world-famous Biomes near St Austell on a quest to brew up a special positive potion which sees them face the Tunnel of Terrors and strut their stuff at the Olive Grooveyard disco.
Ghoulish grub will be on the menu too, including monster ribs, gory guts sausages, roasted bat wings, Day of the Dead vegetable enchiladas, creepy coleslaw and eyeball pizzas.
The Little Monsters’ Ball Halloween disco party on October 31 is a chance for kids to put on their best spooky fancy dress. It’s very popular so best to book in advance.
Admission starts at £22.50 adult/£12.60 child/£62 family. Little Monsters’ Ball £7 per person extra. edenproject.com
East Sussex Scooby-Doo, where are you? At the Drusillas Park zoo in Alfriston on Wednesday, as it happens.
The crime cracking canine will be meeting his fans for the day as part of the attraction’s Halloween Shriek Week, which starts today.
Visitors will also be able explore the creepy corridors of Haunted Heights and encounter witch sisters Hocus and Pocus. Don’t forget the Scooby Snacks! Admission from £16 adult/child £62 family. drusillas.co.uk
Surrey Adult babies, clowns, mime artists and a devilish ringleader are the new stars of the Fright Nights at Thorpe Park.
On selected evenings to November 1, the Chertsey attraction is adding two new horror mazes to the mayhem mix and will have 40 scare actors roaming the site.
The Big Top maze is a creepy, smoky carnival with a terror twist, while Containment challenges guests to race against time to crack codes in an abandoned government facility which has been locked down after medical trials went horribly wrong.
Admission from £25.99, not recommended for under 13s; Containment £10 extra. thorpepark.com
Lancashire Horribly hilarious characters, 800 pumpkins and a range of special effects and stories are awaiting families at The Blackpool Tower Dungeon’s Home of Halloween experience.
Suitable for children aged over eight, it runs to November 1.
And for over 18s only there’s the Where’s Jack? after dark special event of October 30 and 31 where brave guests can join a police hunt for the Ripper.
The quest ends in The Hangman’s Tavern, where there’s a Bloody Mary to calm the nerves.
Home of Halloween costs from £13 adult/£10.50 child. Where’s Jack? is £19.95 per person. thedungeons.com
